Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 04:50PM LilSchatzie wrote: Good luck to you!! I know it must be a rough road you are traveling, but I'm stage iv and my 3 little ones are my life. As much as it hurts me to think they may have to live without me, I couldn't imagine doing this journey without the love and happiness they bring me. I don't personally know anyone that got pregnant stage iv, but I do know of some that found out they had cancer or stage iv during pregnancy. Make sure you look into an OB that has dealth with this. I would guess it's good that you are ER/PR -.
Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 02:40PM LilSchatzie wrote: Thanks to all who have checked out my post. Texasrose, That's great that you are home schooling your 7 year old. I have several friends that homeschool. I love working with my kids, but I don't think I'd be able to homeschool. As much as I lovey kids, I definately need me time to recharge my batteries..,lol Claire, that's cool your parents were stationed in Germany. My dad loved being there. I can't tell you how shocked his parents were when he took home a bride..lol. My mom big joke to my dad was if she waited a little longer she may have met Elvis. I think one of the bases he was stationed at was close to where my mom lived. I hope you got to make your potato pancakes ...sound good! Moira, I definately think this desease has made me focus on what's important...I really hope more and more of us get to live long enough to turn this shitty cancer into a true chronic condition or dare I say cure! Well thanks to all of checked out my answers. I picked the next persons and I will be posting her questions soon!!! Xoxo Karen
Posts.Title: 5 Questions LklSchatzie BaseballFan BaseballFan

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 08:31AM LilSchatzie wrote: Thanks for giving me the opportunity to share more about myself.    1. Why do you call yourself LilSchatzie? LilSchatzie is sort of special to me.  My mom was born in Mannheim Germany.  My Dad was Irish American and in the late 50’s he was stationed in Germany.  My mom worked on the Army base.  She felt like she was a small town girl and she wanted to see the world.  My dad was a dreamer and wanted to show her the world.  So basically they married in Germany when she was 19.  My mom moved to America with my dad.  Growing up Schatzie or Schatz was what my parents called each other.  Not sure of the exact translation but I was told it sort of meant Honey or Sweetheart.  So in the mid 80’s when I was a teenager, my parents got an email account.  My dad was allowed to have 5 email addresses under the account.  His was LuvSchatzie,  I couldn’t think of anything so I used  LilSchatzie.  So now almost 30 years later I still go by LilSchatzie.  So if you ever see a LilSchatzie out their on the web its most likely me. 2. Tell us your favorites. Movie, food, color, actor, actress, music genre, tv show, singer or any other fav you have. It’s funny that you ask me about my favorites.  Being a mom for the last 9 years, in certain ways I feel like I lost myself and everything was about them.  Since getting diagnoised I have tried to remember myself and put myself first and not make everything and every choice about the kids. Movie….I’d say I’m a sappy movie lover.  I really like those feel good movies with Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan.  So I’d say “Sleepless in Seattle”, “When you got mail”, “Hope Floats” and in the classic arena I’d say I liked “It’s A wonderful Life” and “Gone with the wind”.  Also, I must confess probably my least favorite movie, was “The Wizard of Oz”…..those monkeys and witches scared the crap out of me as a kid and I sort of never got into it….But real scary movies I use to love. Food…I’d say  my kids would say I love Salad because I feel its what I eat most of the times when we go out to eat……….But Cheesy….topped Nachos and a margarita……would probably be my real favorite. I love all colors, depend on my mood.  Actors and Actresses, I’d say I never really got into the having a favorite star as an adult….but as a kid John Stamos, John Schneider, Christopher Atkins, can’t think of the others….but I loved Teen Beat and had plenty of posters on the walls. Music, I’d say I love all music.  I can’t carry a tone, but if I’m in my car and a song that comes on that I can blast and sing along with…I’m in heaven.  Music  brings me right back to my youth.  Really calms my soul.  So happy my kids love music too. TV shows, I’d say I like reality TV because It really doesn’t matter if I miss it or not.  I like Big Brother, all the housewives, Amazing Race, Survivor, etc.   I’m not the type that starts talking about it and thinks its real.  I just watch it to take my out of my own crap.   The other shows I watch would be Greys Anatomy, Parenthood, Big Bang Theory….and with my kids we just got into “Good Luck Charlie”.  I also like  documentaries, and history channel.  I love learning new stuff. Inspiration of the moment is people like Kris Carr and David Shevell….(I can’t think of his last name), but I like to read about people living possitively with cancer. 3. Tell us about your family and what they like to do for fun. So first I’ll tell you about my family I grew up with.  I had the greatest parents and siblings.  I was the youngest of 5 kids.  The hardest part of being an adult for me is the losses I’ve had in my family.  In 1990 my oldest brother died from an anerysim at 32.  It was a total shock to us.  At that time they didn’t have the technology they have now, so they caught it when it was happening and he was on life support for a few weeks but was pronouced brain dead almost immediately.  He was single and my mom wanted to donate his organs, but us siblings were in such shook (He was 12 years older then me.) and we thought the doctors were wrong.  He looked perfect….we couldn’t let the plug get pulled….we knew he just had to make it.  The moment he died,  my world was changed for ever.  On Christmas Eve 2002 my dad died at 66 from a long battle with Emphsema.  On March 15, 2008 my brother (my best friend) died from cirrhosis of the liver (I was 8 months pregnant with my little girl).  And just last year my last brother died from Thymus Cancer (He had been in remission and his cancer came back the same month I found out I was stage iv).   I now have just have my mom and my sister. As for my family….. I have a great husband.  He would do anything for me.  I have 3 wonderful kids.  9, 7 & 5.  They are happy and healthy and I couldn’t ask for more when it comes to my kids.  We do lots for fun!  The kids love amusement parks and water parks so we try to get to as many of them as possible and just plan be silly.  I am also sort of active in my church.  With all I been through I think my faith is what gives me the support to keep going.  It gives me the connections to my family members that have passed.  I sort of want my kids to get my stregnth and feel the support of the church when I pass.   Putting my particular religion aside,  I want them to feel like they can go to church or just about go any place and talk to me and feel I’m there with them when they need me in the future when I’m not here.  I also live in the north east area where we have lots of national landmarks and things that we try to get the kids to.  Now that they are getting bigger and I think the older one will appreciate it I want to try to get to landmarks in the south, midwest, and west coast.  Also want to get them to Germany to meet family and I would love to get them to Rome. 4. Describe your city/town. Would you want to live anywhere else? Have you lived anywhere else? I live in a large town in NJ.  I love it because it has everything close by.   I’m definitely not a country girl.  I’d love to go see it and spend some time there and get to know it, but I’m a city girl at heart.  I lived the first 32 years of my life in Brooklyn NY and New York City.  I loved the whole city life….”sex in the city” decade for me.   I didn’t get married until after 30 so I had lots of fun in my twenties.  I worked a job that I traveled a lot and I would see many things.  I did beach houses with friends.  I also did a semester abroad in college and I just loved traveling Europe.  So much fun traveling with friends and staying in hostels.  When I was younger I really wanted to move to the west coast.  My mom discouraged it, she said that I’d miss family and that once you move its hard to go back and find your home….can’t remember exactly how she said it….but she encouraged traveling and seeing things….but not actually moving.   I winded having to move out of the city into the suburbs because of my husbands work, but I’m happy still being close to all I grew up with and feels familier. 5. What are your hobbies? Do you collect anything? Honestly, at this point in my life I’d say my kids are my hobby.  Other than fighting breast cancer and doing and learning everything I can to possibly stick around to see them grow up.  Everything I do and want to do is for them.  I taught them to read with Hooked on Phonics.  I love that they will all (still working with my daughter) know I taught them to read.  Our big thing now is family game night.  I taught my oldest how to play chess, can’t wait to teach the others.  I love to take them out for hikes and walks in nature.  I know I may not have long with them, so I try to be with them for everything.  I sing in church (I can’t sing, but I want them to remember that in mass when they sing Gloria or Alleluia in the catholic mass I sang.)  I also try to teach them its ok to be silly.  I have a laugh that I can play up that will make them laugh for hours.  I’m a stay at home mom so I try to always consider I’m raising adults.  I try to be their for as much as possible, but I also try to give them wings and watch from the side lines to see them fly. As for collections I use to collect things, but now I try not to collect to much.  I’ve saw with all the people I love who passed that when they pass, others don’t treasure those collections the way they did.  It’s so hard to get rid of things that a love one treasured.  So I’d say at this point I don’t really have a collections. Well thanks for giving me the chance to share.  I need to think who I want to ask next. Xoxo Karen

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 02:01PM LilSchatzie wrote: I do whatever I can to offer hope. I think that whatever cancer they have when they are newly diagnoised they need to know that their is hope that they can survive. I usually do it with a card or something really small. It's not until they are in treatment do I send a gift or token if support. I usually send something unsolicited....(cookies, a meal, flowers, book, a religious token, or even a datebook). If the 2 small gestures don't yield a response from the person or the caregiver I usually step back. If I do get a response I usually ask how I can help.

Posts.Title: Who has participated in a BC vaccine trial? BaseballFan LilSchatzie

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 09:55AM LilSchatzie wrote: My brother passed away last week.  I've been spending lots of time around his children (19 & 25).  I was so impressed to hear from my niece that when the cancer came back to him stage iv last year they asked him lots of questions and made him put some of the answers to their questions in writing.  They wanted to know about his childhood.  His relationship with various family members.  Why he chose to marry their mother (they have been divorced 15 years) Why he parented they way he did.  WHy he worked where he worked and basic questions that allowed them to know more about him.  She said that she felt secure in his love for her, she just wanted to know more about him so when life happens she can know that this is how my dad would have done it. As I face my stage iv, my kids are much younger.  It was great for me because I already planned to gather stuff to let them know I loved them.  I might not of thought they wanted to know what life was like for me when I was 8,18,28, 38 etc....
Posts.Title: What should I be doing for my young children 4myangels momto2angels

Posts.Content: LilSchatzie wrote: Last night after my MBC support group I was driving home and feeling hopeful that I just may see my 4 year old daughter grow up. The meeting was uneventful, but I felt like I needed to post here and say that long term survivors are out there...keep going....keep striving for your next milestone. diagnoised with cancer 6/1/11, Stage iv - 7/28/11 - ER/PR + Her2 - lung mets Hormonal Therapy 8/1/2011 Chemotherapy 8/2/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/20/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 8/20/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 08:14PM LilSchatzie wrote: Yeah I'm glad I have a local mets group that is run by a social worker that specializes in breast cancer. There is about 20 women I've met so far. The average meeting gets about 6 members and it's nice because everyone gets a chance to chat and the social worker keeps the pace. Reesie it's the 2nd & 4th Monday @ 7:30. It's the Breast Cancer resource center @ the YWCA in Princeton. You can google the directions. (I'm going to miss the next meeting, but I'll be there in May.)

Posts.Title: thelivesincerelyproject.com penny4cats LilSchatzie

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2013 08:34PM LilSchatzie wrote: My friend son is entering this trial. This poor kid was diagnosed when he was 6 years old. He went through 2 years and 11 months of intense treatments (high dose chemo, spinal taps, lots of side effects). He was needed one more treatment and he thought we would be in remission. They noticed his blood work wasn't bouncing back to get his final treatment. They did more test and discovered he relapsed. Then he had to start treatment all over again. They were unable to get him in remission. Now this trial is his only hope. If the trial doesn't work they really don't have much for him. Cancer just sucks!!! This article makes this trial sound so easy, but when this mom tells you about all the potential things that could happen to her child going into this trial..,,it's just so scary.

Posts.Title: A BRAND NEW YEAR! scuttlers lulubee

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 07:33AM LilSchatzie wrote: Hi 4MyAngels, Welcome to the stage iv boards. I was diagnosed stage iv last year with lung mets and auxiliary node mets. I was put on Tamoxifen in the beginning of August and Lupron 4weeks later. I could feel the Auxiliary node reducing in size within about 6 weeks of starting hormonals. My October pet scan didn't pick up the lung mets and showed a reduction in the size of auxiliary node. It's a great drug start with. As far as side effects go, I really didn't have any other then hot flashes and stiff joints. I find taking the tamoxifen at night it helped with the flashes. As far as the stiff joints, exercise really helps with that.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 09:09AM LilSchatzie wrote: Welcome, I'm so sorry you are joining us. I was diagnosed stage iv from the start last year. I had 3 young kids...(3,5,7). In the beginning it is hard to get your head around it, but it gets easier. What works for me is I gathered myself a medical team I trust. I also try to live in the moment with my children making memories and trying to set up routines with them so that if my health changes, they have the security of those routines. in the beginning I shared everything with my friends, as I move further along I now only share with my friends what they need to know. So far I've been on a hormonal, a vaccine trial and now Xeloda....if you met me on the street you wouldn't even know I had cancer. For the most part I like it that way. When I freak out with scans or treatments I come to these boards or other stage iv support systems I set up over the last year and a half. These ladies are great and don't fret, there is plenty of love and hope out there for us. Xoxo Karen

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 02:39PM - edited Apr 29, 2012 02:43PM by LilSchatzie I didn't like this article at all.  I think this doctor is in the wrong profession if she thinks that she can be judge for every person coming into the ICU.  I get that it must get frustrating treating people and then having them do nothing to help themselves....but honestly don't we all face that as parents, teachers, family memebers and such.  I think this is just an example of blaming the victimn.  I get that as a doctor, if you have a private practice you can have some control over what patients you accept into your practice...but give me a break... an ICU doctor doing rounds.  I think they should just treat and advise their patients through.  Who knows their conversation with the patient may just be the turning point for a patient.  If this doctor really wanted to do some good, she could....but to me she sounds like she has given up on her patients before they even passed through the doors..  In my opinion this doctor isn't God and doesn't have a right to pass such harsh judgement.
Posts.Title: Doctors who think they are God CoolBreeze CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 09:28AM LilSchatzie wrote: My thought, based on conversation with my Onc regarding my situation is that the liver met is small so it would be your choice to try an AI or chemo. If you tried one of the AI's you haven't tried yet and the next ct showed progression your next treatment would be chemo because it seems chemo response is usually quicker then hormones. However if you choose a chemo and it go her to stable. Next treatment would

Posts.Title: Afinitor is my new BFF BaseballFan sueco

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 06:57AM LilSchatzie wrote: It is so had with the young kids. Mine are 8, 6, & 3. My mom and I are so close and I'm 43 and I can't imagine her not in my life and it hurts me to think that it will take a miracle for my kids to have their mother as long as I had mine. I really want to be there for them. What helps me get through it is my life experiences and by living in the moment. I have friends that have lost their parents young and they turned out to be great adults. I know it sucks that I won't see all the milestones, but it helps me to think they can turn ok like some of my friends. I try to live in the moment and because right now I feel ok I try to keep their lives as normal as possible. The other day I turned 43 and I thought to myself I want to make 50 so bad. If I can get my little one to at least 10....I can set another goal...to get her to 15. It's such a scary journey, but my current motto is "why not me". As long as I keep hearing stories of long term survivors....."why not me!"........"why not you!"......"why not all of us!".......something may switch the switch and many of us could be love survivors.....why not!!! I believe in us all! Xoxo Karen

Posts.Title: OT-Valerie Harper diagnosed with brain cancer DivineMrsM LilSchatzie

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 10:16AM LilSchatzie wrote: Hugs, I totally understand what you are going through. It's so hard to go through this with young kids. As a parent you want to do everything to protect them. Knowing that you can't protect them from this is my biggest struggle as a parent. Last year I was diagnoised stage iv from the get go. My kids were 7, 5 & 3. I spoke to lots of people regarding talking to the kids. I was told that I should tell them I have cancer and use real words. What they can imagine on their own is much worse then what I can say to them. Also it makes them secure (even if it's bad news) that they hear it first from a parent or a caregiver. I've never said i will die from the cancer. I was told not to plant thoughts in their heads, however i should try to answer their questions as they come up honestly. For example yes people can die from cancer, but my doctors are treating me and doing everything to keep me healthy. So i have been honest with the kids, but Overwhelmingly I was told to follow my heart and do what I think is best for my children
Posts.Title: Mommy please don't die! stagefree SPAMgirl

Posts.Title: Scan Results Tomorrow CoolBreeze Brendatrue

Posts.Content: LilSchatzie wrote: I guess i just need to release this so i can move on. I was diagnosed stage iv at initial diagnosis in July with lung mets. Like many of you i was all set to have a mastectomy and because they found the lung mets my surgery was canceled. Last week I had a PET exam and yesterday reviewed results with doctor. I should be excited that my lungs show no evidence of disease, but i'm really not happy. The report shows only slite improvement in the breast and lymph nodes when compared with last PET. Its possible that the month i went getting the lung biopsy my grade 3 cancer grew aggressively so cimparing this one to that one isn't a true picture of 3 months of treatment. Well yesterday i told my friends my news about my lungs being ned on the scan, but didn't really get into the breast cancer and they are so happy for me, but i sort of feel numb. Not sad, but not happy either. But i think what pushed to post is this morning i looked at my lab results and both my tumor cancer markers they check went up. I'm not to worried about the markers because the one is 29 and the other one is 5 so I know they aren't that high and are greatly debated....but it still didn't help my mood today. On possitive note doctor said i could probably get a bmx and next week going to john hopkins to get on the vacine trial. Ok...now i feel a little better. I'm glad i have a place to share my hinest thoughts. Karen diagnoised with cancer 6/1/11, Stage iv - 7/28/11 - ER/PR + Her2 - lung mets Hormonal Therapy 8/1/2011 Chemotherapy 8/2/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/20/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 8/20/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 07:43AM LilSchatzie wrote: I was recently in a clinical trial and I needed to get approval from my insurance company. The clinical trial coordinator did most of the leg work with insurance company. All trials may work differently, but how mine worked was the trial paid for all the meds and treatments and blood draws that we're unique to the trial. My insurance was billed for all the scans and test that were standard for a stage iv cancer patient. Who would pay for what was worked out before the trial started. Michele, I totally believe in clinical trials. Of corse you need to do your own research and make sure it's safe and worth it for yourself. Many long term survivors I have met that have had all types of cancers have done very well with clinical trials with very little side effects. At your stage, I would definately consider phase ii trials because their is usually a limited time in our journey when we are eligible. Phase I trials are usually more of a risk that can usually be taken once you use up more standard treatment! Good luck!!! We are all routing for you! Xo Karen

Posts.Title: Lowrider, Facebook post mnmom3

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 09:58AM LilSchatzie wrote: Thanks for the article, I think it had some encouraging info for me. I started a phase ii vaccine trial at John Hopkins. I know several ladies from this forum have been in vaccine clinical trials with mixed results. Thanks to anyone that has participated in a vaccine trial, I think it's important in getting the science to find a cure for us and our children. Anyone that is considering a vaccine trial don't be discouraged by mixed results. All treatments have mixed results, there is no silver bullet out there at this point. I think the earlier in your treatment you try one the better. There is really a lot of science out there that says even if you progress on the vaccine it's still in your system and may help your next treatments. Good luck to all!!

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2013 11:20AM LilSchatzie wrote: As much as I was disappointed, anyone who reads this who hasn't been to a conference I would encourage to try to get to atleast one conference and make your own opinions. I think we are a well educated group of women. I think many of us do our own research and get so much information from each other that we must be hard to present to. I did get a lot from seeing the women stand up that were 10, 15, 20, etc. metastatic thrivers. Also it was encouraging to see all the beautiful metestatic women walking around with metastatic disease and know your not the only one. I guess what was most disappointing for me was that I showed up by myself running a little late and I sort of felt a clicky vibe. I didn't feel guided in a place to sit, I wasn't sure who came as a group and who were meeting there for the first time. Also some responses in the audience to the presenters were started as myself and others in my situation feel a certain way. Even though sometimes I agreed it made me feel like their was a group of people talking and making opinions that I didn't know about. In away it made me feel like I was in high school and didn't have a click. I really didn't mind not having a click because I'm not a click person but I really would have loved to meet some people, but I really would of had to put myself out there for that to happy and I guess I wasn't in the mood.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 05:05PM LilSchatzie wrote: Good luck ma, this all is so frustrating. I filed online and forward them my files I received from the onc office. My onc's nurse was horrible telling me I don't qualify for disability and that she wasn't going to lie for me. I was so pissed off at her. I told her I don't expect her to lie for me...yes physically I'm fine at the moment but mentally I'm not in the position to go looking for a job. I had enough credits from before I decided to stay home with the kids to qualify. Honestly I don't know how she filled them out, but I forwarded my doctors records that stated that I was terminal. Long story short. I was approved! Good Luck!!

Posts.Title: LBBC Conference - disappointed reader123 steelrose

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 06:07AM LilSchatzie wrote: Hugs Anko, I know what you are going through, my kids are 8, 6, and 4. As a parent, I think it's great to put these questions out there to see what others do. Over the last year I have learned so much from others on these boards. I try to be honest with my kids, give them opportunities to ask questions....also we use a lot of humor. So if my child ask a question like are you going to die....I would say something like "everyone dies eventually" and sort of make a joke about question I wonder what it would look like to live to 200 years old. My big message to my kids is, even if I am sad that I have cancer I'm not afraid and I (or should I say we (my husband) are there for them to answer any questions they have. I also push the message that as a family we live in the moment and don't worry about the future. I know my to older boys get that message. Last week my 8 & 6 year old needed to wear sneakers (yeah I'm from NY) so my 6 year old had had Velcro ties but my 8 year old had tie shoelaces and he had not worn tie shoes all Summer and he forgot how to tie. So I had to tie his shoes and I was lecturing him on what's he going to do next week when he is at camp? Then my 6 year old chimed into his defense and said "Mom, let's worry about today. Let's not start worry about next week today. Lol I have to tell you it almost made me cry. They totally get my message of living in the moment ". So I'm not sure if I made any point with my rambling post. I just want you to know, you are the parent and you know your child...follow your instincts. Nobody knows what's better for your child then you. It's great to get ideas from others, but only apply what you think will be of benefit to your child. Xoxo Karen
Posts.Title: Stage IV and young children Anko66 Moderators

Posts.Content: LilSchatzie wrote: Does anyone have any experience with Chemo Sensitivity Resistance Assays (CSRA's) testing?  When I was first diagnoised with stage iv my mom's neighbor who is doing a film documentary on it gave my mom all this information on it to give me.  I basically took the info and put it in a drawer and never looked at it.  At the time I was getting so much info from different directions that I forgot she even gave it to me.  So today I pulled the info and video out and watched the trailer he gave me.  It looks very interesting....so now I'm going to make my mom ask him what ever happend to the documentary.  I can't find anything through google.  Either way, I'm thinking of contacting the doctor that was filmed and looking into this as a second opinion.  The doctors look ligit and don't raise any red flags for me when I googled them. Just curious if anyone has been through CSRA testing and if it was worth it. Thanks, Karen diagnoised with cancer 6/1/11, Stage iv - 7/28/11 - ER/PR + Her2 - lung mets Hormonal Therapy 8/1/2011 Chemotherapy 8/2/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/20/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 8/20/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply
